title: Hell For Leather
description: OpenGL Racing Game with a Physically Based Rendering (PBR) pipeline, custom vehicle physics, and optimized real-time collision and suspension dynamics.
longDescription: This 3D racing simulation was a third-year OpenGL project focused on implementing advanced graphics and physics systems from the ground up. The project features a complete Physically Based Rendering (PBR) pipeline for realistic, physically-grounded materials and lighting, all set within a 3D skybox. A core technical component is the optimized collision engine, which uses a spatial grid to accelerate queries. This allows for real-time suspension physics (via ray-triangle intersection queries) and accurate track collisions (via AABB checks). The demo is complete with vehicle physics, a flexible follow-cam, 3D model loading via Assimp, and a full UI with a lap timer.

features.name: Physically Based Rendering (PBR) for realistic lighting and materials on the car and track.

Optimized Collision Detection: Employs a spatial grid to accelerate all collision queries. This structure enables fast ray-triangle intersection queries (with all four wheels) and AABB-triangle checks (for side impacts against the track's geometry).

Flexible Camera Controller: Features a dynamic follow-cam that tracks the car, pulling back at high speeds and shifting during turns. The system also allows the user to take manual control and orbit the camera.
Sound Management: A central sound system manages all game audio, like engine sounds and effects.
UI & Text: Renders text on-screen for the HUD, including a lap timer, best lap display, and a car selection menu.
Vehicle Physics: Includes handling for acceleration, braking, steering and jumping to make the driving feel more believable.
Lap Timer: Uses a 3D trigger volume at the finish line to accurately track lap times and save the best-lap record.
3D Environment: Skybox to create the 3D sky and background.

title: GPU Flour Sifting Animation
description: A high-performance particle simulation modeling granular materials using OpenGL Compute Shaders with real-time accumulation and dynamic collisions.
longDescription: This project is a high-performance simulation of granular materials, specifically flour, implemented using OpenGL and C++. The core of the simulation runs on the GPU via Compute Shaders, managing the physics and collision detection for a massive number of particles without CPU bottlenecks. A key feature is the heightmap accumulation system, which uses atomic image operations to allow particles to pile up realistically on a surface, dynamically modifying the terrain. The simulation also features a procedural collision system for the sifter, approximating a wire mesh grid to filter particles based on their trajectory and the sieve's movement.

features.name: Compute Shader Architecture: Offloaded physics calculations (gravity, velocity integration) to the GPU, enabling the simulation of massive particle counts at real-time framerates.
Heightmap Accumulation: Implemented a deposition algorithm using GLSL `imageAtomicAdd` to transfer particle mass to a 2D texture, creating accurate piles and terrain deformation.

Procedural Mesh Collision: Developed a shader-based collision system that analytically models the sifter's wire grid (`sifterBarAt`), allowing particles to either bounce off wires or pass through holes based on position.
Dynamic Sifter Animation: Integrated a sine-wave based motion controller to simulate the shaking and sifting action, which directly influences particle momentum.
Particle Recycling System: Implemented a boundary check system that seamlessly respawns particles falling below the kill-plane, ensuring a continuous flow of material.

title: HMD Navigator
description: A Mixed Reality prototype leveraging Meta Quest 3's Passthrough and Depth APIs for real-time marker detection and world-space alignment.
longDescription: HMD Navigator is a technical research prototype designed to investigate the capabilities of the Meta Quest 3's advanced mixed reality sensors. The project focuses on integrating the new Passthrough and Depth APIs to detect physical markers directly from the headset's camera feed. The core utility involves mapping these detected markers to 3D world space to facilitate precise user positioning. The project involved extensive device-level experimentation to evaluate the stability and limitations of the Quest 3's spatial mapping technology in real-world environments.

features.name: Investigated Meta Quest 3’s new Passthrough and Depth APIs to prototype marker detection directly from the camera feed.
Implemented a depth-based world-space positioning system by casting rays into the environment to estimate the physical location of detected markers.
Built a user–marker calibration method that determines the user’s position relative to the closest marker, enabling alignment with a virtual navigation graph.
Conducted technical experimentation and device-level testing to evaluate the accuracy, stability, and limitations of the implemented marker detection system.
Live Map Display: Renders an interactive 3D model of the environment that tracks and follows the user's hand in real-time.
Route Selection: Allows users to select a destination on the live map to generate a virtual path, calculating the route on the digital twin.

imgAlt: Real time Ray Tracing with CUDA
title: Real time Ray Tracing with CUDA
description: An extension of a professor-provided real-time CUDA ray tracing engine. The project implements ray tracing for triangles, procedurally generated object textures, interactive camera movements, and dynamic collision detection in real-time.
longDescription: This project is an interactive mini-game built for a low-level programming class, extending a real-time CUDA ray tracing engine provided by my professor. The experience takes the user through multiple unique rooms using WASD controls. It begins in an Infinity Mirrors room, inspired by Yayoi Kusama, which uses highly reflective surfaces to create a visually infinite space. The final room features dynamic, floating spheres that collide and bounce off the environment in real-time.

features.name: Extended the ray tracer to render complex triangle meshes, not just the original spheres.
Implemented real-time physics for sphere-to-sphere and sphere-to-triangle-surface collisions.
Procedurally generated unique patterns for the surface materials.
Created a system for materials and colors to update dynamically based on user interaction.
Designed a multi-room experience with WASD navigation.
Built a dynamic scene where floating, refractive spheres realistically bounce off surfaces and eachother

title: SoteriaXR - Fire Escape Training
description: Customizable fire escape training tool developed for the Meta Quest 3.
longDescription: This project is a Mixed Reality (MR) training application developed for the Meta Quest 3 headset, designed to overcome the limitations of traditional and generic Virtual Reality safety programs. By blending virtual hazards and tools directly into the user's actual physical environment, Soteria XR provides highly personalized and practical fire safety drills. A central feature is the customizable scenario editor, which allows users to map fire locations and necessary equipment to their real surroundings, ensuring the training is relevant to the space they inhabit every day.

features.name: Scene Manager uses the Meta Quest MR Utility Kit (MRUK) to scan and load the user's real-world room spatial data, perform checks and prompts spatial scans if unavailable. Ensuring virtual hazards and equipment are perfectly aligned with physical furniture and walls.

Custom Scenario Editor: A runtime editor allows the user to freely position virtual fire hazards, alarms, fire extinguishers, and exit points within their scanned environment to design unique training situations.
Scenario setups, including object placements and positions, are accurately saved using Spatial Anchors and a custom JSON system so that custom layouts persist and can be reloaded across sessions.

Fire Simulation: Fire and sprinkler behavior relies on a Voxel Grid system based on the room's spatial data; extinguishing is managed by a voxel health system that uses raycast intersection calculations (for the extinguisher and sprinklers) to reduce fire damage
Fire extinguishers are fully interactive, requiring the user to physically remove the safety pin and operate the nozzle by following the official P.A.S.S. method
The application includes two modes: a Step-by-Step Training Mode with continuous guided dialogue and an Unguided Testing Mode for autonomous performance evaluation.
A Score System tracks adherence to safety protocol and remaining health, providing a final score and detailed checklist feedback on all completed and missed steps.

title: Ticking Tea Time
description: A 2D point-and-click detective game built on a custom engine.
longDescription: Developed as a second-year group project, Ticking Tea Time is a 2D point-and-click detective adventure built entirely on a custom C++ game engine. Players take on the role of an undercover waiter on the Hesperia Express, using tea service as a cover to investigate suspects and defuse a ticking bomb. The game seamlessly blends kitchen simulation mechanics with deep, branching storytelling. It has been widely recognized for its narrative depth and technical execution, garnering over 600 downloads and winning both the BIDC Rising Star Award and the PlayPrime Award for Best Narrative at the Thailand International Game Showcase 2024.

features.name: Input & UI Systems: Implemented robust input handling and UI systems essential for point-and-click gameplay, including interactive menus and pop-ups to enhance usability.
Interactive Journal: Developed a key gameplay mechanic—the interactive journal—utilizing backend data management to dynamically reflect player progress and gathered clues.
Kitchen Simulation: Designed and implemented the kitchen simulation scenes, creating intricate UI logic to manage tea preparation mechanics.
Dialogue System Integration: Built a flexible event system that streamlined dialogue integration, enabling the team to easily trigger branching narrative events based on player choices.
Award-Winning: Recognized with BIDC's Rising Star Awards for Game 2024 and the PlayPrime Award for Best Narrative for its engaging storytelling and design.
Custom Engine Architecture: The game is built from the ground up using a custom 2D game engine written in C++.
